events.description: Soybean futures in the US reached a 2-month high of $11.15 per bushel in February.

events.event_name: Trump's announcement on Chinese soybean purchases
events.description: President Trump stated China would increase purchases of US soybeans to 20 million tonnes this year and 25 million tonnes next year.
A strong harvest in Brazil, the world's top producer, affecting global supply and premiums.

facts.fact_text: Soybean futures in the US reached $11.15 per bushel in February, the highest in two months.

evidences.evidence_text: Soybean futures in the US extended their rally to $11.15 per bushel in February, the highest in two months

facts.fact_text: Donald Trump stated China would lift purchases of domestic soybeans to 20 million tonnes this year and 25 million tonnes next year.

evidences.evidence_text: President Donald Trump stated that China would lift purchases of domestic soybeans to 20 million tonnes this year and 25 million tonnes in the upcoming year.

facts.fact_text: Brazil is the world's top producer of soybeans.
US premiums over CBOT contracts are nearly double those from Brazilian benchmarks.

evidences.evidence_text: US premiums over CBOT contracts to hover nearly double those from Brazilian benchmarks.

claims.claim_text: The purchase measures are an attempt by Trump to gain support from farmers.

evidences.evidence_text: The measures signal the attempt by Trump to engage support for farmers after China shunned US grain following the trade war between both countries.

claims.claim_text: Chinese consumers might pay premiums on 8 million tonnes of orders compared to cheaper South American alternatives.

evidences.evidence_text: The pledges could drive Chinese consumers to pay premiums on 8 million tonnes of the orders when compared to cheaper South American alternatives

evidence.evidence_text: Soybean futures in the US extended their rally to $11.15 per bushel in February... on renewed interest in US soybean shipments from China.
China shunned US grain following the trade war between both countries.
Ample supply from Brazil, the world's top producer, drove US premiums over CBOT contracts to hover nearly double those from Brazilian benchmarks.
